message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prolonged constipation, vomiting, and abdominal pain with distention suggest that the most likely underlying cause is malrotation of the gut. Volvulus may present similarly but there will be signs of ischemia and bloody stools. Pyloric stenosis typically presents with projectile vomiting in the first weeks of life, and Meckel’s diverticulum usually presents with acute pain that comes and goes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The girl’s symptoms, including persistent abdominal pain, constipation, distended upper abdomen, and vomiting, are indicative of a malrotation of the gut. Volvulus can cause similar symptoms but typically presents with bloody stools. Pyloric stenosis would not cause constipation, and Meckel’s diverticulum would not typically present with persistent abdominal pain, constipation, and vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of persistent abdominal pain, worsening constipation, and vomiting, along with the absence of bowel movements and flatulence for 72 hours, suggest a possible obstruction. The upper abdominal distension and tympany suggest the obstruction is in the small bowel. Malrotation of the gut is the most likely cause as it can lead to a closed-loop obstruction. Volvulus can also cause a closed-loop obstruction, but it is more common in the sigmoid colon. Pyloric stenosis affects the stomach and is not likely to cause constipation. Meckel’s diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that can cause obstruction but is unlikely to present with these symptoms at this age.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The girl’s symptoms of abdominal pain, constipation, vomiting, and abdominal distension suggest a gastrointestinal issue. The fact that she has not passed flatulence or bowel movement in 72 hours and the upper abdomen is distended and tympanic indicates malrotation of the gut as the most likely underlying cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent abdominal pain, worsening constipation, and vomiting suggest intestinal obstruction. Malrotation of the gut is the most likely cause in this case, as it is a congenital abnormality that commonly manifests in early childhood and can lead to intestinal obstruction. Volvulus can also cause intestinal obstruction and can occur at any age but usually presents with sudden onset of severe symptoms. Pyloric stenosis and Meckel's diverticulum do not typically present with constipation or intestinal obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent abdominal pain, constipation, vomiting, and abdominal distension suggest the most likely underlying cause is malrotation of the gut. Volvulus and Meckel’s diverticulum also present with symptoms like abdominal pain and vomiting, but they usually occur in older children or adults. Pyloric stenosis usually presents with projectile vomiting and is more common in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent abdominal pain accompanied by constipation, vomiting, and a distended and tympanic upper abdomen suggests malrotation of the gut. Volvulus would have abdominal masses, Pyloric stenosis would have forceful vomiting, and Meckel’s diverticulum would have bloody stools.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent abdominal pain, worsening constipation, vomiting, and no bowel movement or flatulence in 72 hours suggest a possible obstruction. The upper abdominal distension and tympany suggest the obstruction is in the upper portion of the intestine, narrowing the choices to Pyloric stenosis and Malrotation of the gut. However, Pyloric stenosis usually presents in the first few weeks of life and Meckel’s diverticulum often presents with painless rectal bleeding. Therefore, Malrotation of the gut is the most likely underlying cause of the girl’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent abdominal pain, constipation, vomiting, and distended upper abdomen suggest malrotation of the gut. Volvulus usually presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and Meckel's diverticulum typically presents with painless rectal bleeding. Pyloric stenosis presents with projectile vomiting in an infant in the first few weeks of life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an obstructive process in the bowel, possibly due to malrotation of the gut. Volvulus will cause abdominal distension and pain. Pyloric stenosis will cause projectile vomiting but not constipation. Meckel's diverticulum, a common congenital anomaly affecting the digestive tract, may cause abdominal pain and diarrhea but is unlikely to cause the symptoms described in this case.
